author: Robert Higgs, Northeast Ohio Media Group Columbus bureau chief
title: Early voting begins today: Here's the how and when for voting in November's general election
text:
COLUMBUS, Ohio -- Early voting for the Nov. 3 general election begins Tuesday, offering Ohioans more than 200 hours to vote early in person at their county boards of elections and 24/7 voting access at their kitchen table with an absentee ballot.
On the ballot are three proposed amendments to the Ohio Constitution.
Issue 1 would change how boundaries are drawn for the state's legislative districts. Issue 2 would bar monopolies from being written into the state constitution. Issue 3 would legalize medical and recreational use of marijuana and open the door to a multimillion-dollar marijuana industry in Ohio. In addition, voters will decide 1,736 local issues, including taxes for police and fire services and school funding. Thousands of local offices in communities and school districts across Ohio also are up for a vote.
Information on the state issues is available on the Ohio secretary of state's website. The Know the Issues page includes ballot language for the issues as well as pro and con arguments for each.
Also posted online is information about how to vote and where. The My Ohio Vote page has instructions for applying for absentee ballots, voting early in person at the county elections board, finding polling places, what identification is required and answers to other frequently asked questions.
Early in-person voting hours will be from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. on weekdays this week and for the next two weeks. For the week before the election, early voting will be available from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. on weekdays.
Weekend voting will be available Oct. 31, the Saturday before Election Day, from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. and Nov. 1 (Sunday) from 1 to 5 p.m. Early voting also will be available from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. on Nov. 2, the Monday before Election Day.
Boards of elections began mailing absentee ballots Tuesday to those who have put in requests. The deadline for requesting an absentee ballot by mail is noon on Oct. 31.
Voted ballots returned by mail must be postmarked no later than Nov. 2 and must be received by county elections boards no later than Nov. 13.
Absentee ballots may also be hand delivered to boards of elections until the close of the polls on Election Day. They may not be returned at polling locations.
Polls will be open on Election Day from 6:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m.
